metadata.title: Contribution of autophagy machinery factors to HCV and SARS-CoV-2 replication organelle formation

abstract.text: This is a PDF file of an article that has undergone enhancements after acceptance, such as the addition of a cover page and metadata, and formatting for readability, but it is not yet the definitive version of record. J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f Contribution of autophagy machinery factors to 1 HCV and SARS-CoV-2 replication organelle 2 formation 3 4 Woan-Summary 1 Positive-strand RNA viruses replicate in close association with rearranged 2 intracellular membranes. For hepatitis C virus (HCV) and SARS-CoV-2, these 3 rearrangements comprise ER-derived double membrane vesicles (DMVs) serving 4 as RNA replication sites. Cellular factors involved in DMV biogenesis are poorly 5 defined. Here, we show that despite structural similarity of viral DMVs with 6 autophagosomes, conventional macroautophagy is dispensable for HCV and 7 SARS-CoV-2 replication. However, both viruses exploit factors involved in 8 autophagosome formation, most notably class III phosphatidylinositol-3 kinase 9 (PI3K). As revealed with a biosensor, PI3K is activated in cells infected with either 10 virus to produce PI3P while kinase complex inhibition or depletion profoundly 11 reduces replication and viral DMV formation. The PI3P-binding protein DFCP1 12 recruited to omegasomes in early steps of autophagosome formation, participates in 13 replication and DMV formation of both viruses. These results indicate that 14 phylogenetically unrelated HCV and SARS-CoV-2 exploit similar components of the 15 autophagy machinery to create their replication organelles. 16 17

For SARS-CoV-2, we analyzed DMV formation in an analogous manner using 266 the HA-nsp3-4-V5 expression construct and 1 µM PIK-III, corresponding to ~10x 267 EC50. However, the exact function of the protein 286 Consistent with the earlier report, DFCP1 KD significantly reduced HCV replication 295 ( Figure 5C ). To study the effect of DFCP1 KD on SARS-CoV-2 replication, we used 296 A549/ACE2 cells. Also in these cells, KD efficiency was high and did not affect cell 297 viability ( Figure 5D and 5E, respectively). Notably, DFCP1 KD also drastically 298 reduced SARS-CoV-2 replication ( Figure 5F ). 299

To examine the role of DFCP1 in DMV formation, we employed our 300 expression-based systems to avoid confounding effects caused by replication 301 inhibition resulting from DFCP1 KD. For HCV, Huh7-Lunet/T7 cells were transfected 302 with either DFCP1 siRNA or the non-targeting control, followed by transfection with 303 the NS3-5B expression construct. In this case we used a variant of this construct 304 function ( Figure 6B ) (Schaller et al., 2007) . This variant was employed because we 306 analyzed the cells by correlative light and electron microscopy (CLEM) in order to 307 make sure that analyzed cells indeed had been transfected. Forty-eight hours after 308 transfection, cells were harvested and analyzed by western blotting and CLEM. KD 309 with either siRNA reduced DFCP1 to below our western blotting detection limit, while 310 it did not affect expression level of NS5A EGFP (note that the double band corresponds 311 to basal and hyperphosphorylated NS5A) ( Figure 6A ). Analysis of fixed cells by 312 CLEM revealed significant reduction of DMV abundance by KD with either siRNA as 313 compared to cells transfected with the control siRNA ( Figure 6B and 6C) . 314

In the case of SARS-CoV-2, we conducted the analogous experiments but using 315 a monocistronic expression construct encoding NeonGreen followed by 316 HA-nsp3-4-V5 ( Figure 6E ), with NeonGreen allowing the identification of transfected 317 cells and correlation with EM images and the HA-tag allowing the detection of 318 processed HA-nsp3. Consistent with the replication data, KD of DFCP1 also 319 impaired DMV formation induced by SARS-CoV-2 HA-nsp3-4-V5, which was not 320 due to effects of DFCP1 depletion on HA-nsp3-4-V5 abundance ( Figure 6D to 6F). 321

Taken together, our data suggest that DFCP1 is a critical host factor for efficient 322 replication of HCV and SARS-CoV-2. The most likely contribution of DFCP1 to 323 replication is to support the biogenesis of DMVs, which are the predominant 324 elements of the replication organelles and the sites of HCV and SARS-CoV-2 RNA 325
replication.

Earlier studies suggest that the ATG5-12/16L1 332 complex is required for HCV replication (Dreux et al., 2009; Fahmy et al., 2018; 333 Fahmy and Labonté, 2017; Guévin et al., 2010; Tanida et al., 2009), which is at 334 variance to our results showing that KO of ATG5 and ATG16L1 does not affect HCV 335 replication. This inconsistency might result from the different approaches used to 336 inhibit ATG proteins. While earlier studies employed siRNA KD, which might have 337 caused insufficient depletion of ATG proteins, we used CRISPR/Cas9-based KO 338 cells unable to express targeted genes. Although during selection for KO cells, we 339 might have enriched for cells compensating the defect, such as upregulation of 340 ATG16L2 replacing ATG16L1 in the complex with ATG5-12 (Ishibashi et al., 2011), 341 we note that two functional assays demonstrated a block of 342 ATG5-12/16L1-dependent autophagy in our cell pools, yet virus replication was not 343 significantly affected. In the case of coronaviruses, the role of ATG5 for viral 344 replication is discussed controversially. Prentice and colleagues report that MHV 345 replication is strongly reduced by ATG5 KO (Prentice et al., 2004a; Prentice et al., used in these studies, but further studies are required to clarify these 350 inconsistencies. 351 By using a biosensor, we found that PI3P levels are upregulated in HCV and 352 SARS-CoV-2 infected cells. This elevation appears to be important for viral 353 replication, because treatment of the cells with the class III PI3K-specific inhibitor 354 PIK-III reduced HCV and SARS-CoV-2 replication, consistent with previous studies 355 employing other PI3K inhibitors (Mohl et al., 2016; Silvas et al., 2020; Williams et al., 356 2021; Yuen et al., 2020). However, VPS34 is involved in autophagy and endocytic 357 pathways (Jaber et al., 2016; Juhász et al., 2008), raising the question whether the 358 PI3P we detected resides on autophagy-related membranes directly involved in 359 DMV formation or on endosomal membranes involved in cargo transport to DMV 360 formation sites. Although the role of PI3P in endosomal transport processes such as 361 the delivery of cholesterol to HCV-induced DMVs cannot be excluded (Stoeck et al., 362 2018), our data suggest that PI3P produced by PI3K is directly involved in HCV and 363 SARS-CoV-2 replication. Consistent with this assumption, KD or KO of ATG14L 364 (Lee et al., 2019a) and depletion of Beclin 1 (Figure S2) (Gassen et al., 2021), which 365 are both components of the PI3K complex (Figure 1A), inhibit HCV replication.

Sensitivity of this probe for PI3P was validated by the lack of 394 its recruitment when using a PI3P non-binding DFCP1 mutant, arguing against the 395 possibility that the probe was recruited by the DFCP1 moiety independent from 396 PI3P. With respect to HCV, our results are supported by a previous study showing 397 that the PI3K inhibitor 3-methyladenine (3-MA) or VPS34 KD reduce the abundance 398 of LC3-II in HCV infected cells and HCV replication, respectively (Su et al., 2011). In 399 contrast, two other studies report that inhibition of PI3P production neither affects 400 HCV-induced LC3 lipidation, nor DFCP1 puncta formation (Mohl et al., 2016; Sir et 401 al., 2012). One possible explanation for these discrepancies might be the use of 402 different 3-MA treatment durations, ranging from 3 to 40 h between the different 403 studies. Another explanation could be the different assay used to determine HCV 404 replication. 405 In the case of coronaviruses, lipidation or redistribution of LC3 has been 406 described for cells infected with transmissible gastroenteritis virus and infectious 407 bronchitis virus (Cottam et al., 2011; Guo et al., 2016). In contrast, Reggiori and 408 co-workers reported an association between MHV-induced DMVs and non-lipidated 409 LC3 and the importance of non-lipidated LC3 for replication and DMV formation 410 (Reggiori et al., 2010). Since the presence of LC3-I is a marker for ERAD vesicles 411 (Cali et al., 2008a; Cali et al., 2008b), this study suggests that the ERAD pathway, 412 rather than autophagy, is hijacked by MHV for DMV formation. Notably, we did not 413 strategies might be used by different coronaviruses for DMV formation. 415 While we provide evidence that the class III PI3K is required for HCV-and 416 SARS-CoV-2-induced DMV formation, the turn-over of these structures remains 417 unclear. As shown in a recent publication, DMVs induced by MHV are subjected to 418 lysosomal degradation late in infection when the ER becomes the main budding 419 compartment for new virions (Mihelc et al., 2021). At least in the expression-based 420 systems, we neither observed enhanced degradation of HA-nsp3 upon PI3K 421 inhibition (Figure 4E, S6D), nor colocalization with LAMP1 (Figure S6F), arguing 422 against DMV degradation. Further studies will be required to dissect DMV turn-over 423 in the case of SARS-CoV-2. 424 We have recently shown that NS5A, in cooperation with RACK1, facilitates the 425 formation of the class III PI3K complex (Lee et al., 2019a). Here, we further 426 investigated how NS5A affects PI3P production and thus, DMV formation. Inhibition 427 of NS5A by Daclatasvir strongly reduced NS3-5B induced GFP-DFCP1 puncta 428 formation. This effect was specific as PI3P levels were unaffected by Daclatasvir in 429 cells expressing a drug-resistant replicase, indicating that NS5A is involved in 430 HCV-induced PI3P production, consistent with our earlier report showing that 431 Daclatasvir blocks HCV-induced DMV formation. 432 DFCP1 is a PI3P effector protein that, upon starvation, associates with 433 omegasomes (Axe et al., 2008; Nanao et al., 2015). However, the exact function of 434 this protein in autophagy remains unclear. Recent evidence suggests that DFCP1 435 and the ER (Gao et al., 2019; Li et al., 2019). Here, we show that DFCP1 positively 437 regulates HCV and SARS-CoV-2 replication, possibly by promoting formation of 438 DMVs, the replication sites of these viruses. We previously observed 439 DMV-decorated ER wrapping around lipid droplets in HCV infected cells (Lee et al., 440 2019b), arguing that DFCP1 might affect DMV formation through regulating the 441 contact between ER and lipid droplets, at least in HCV. Although it is unclear 442 whether the same applies to SARS-CoV-2, we note that lipid droplets have been 443 observed in close proximity of virus particles and it has been proposed that lipid 444 droplets might serve as an assembly platform (Dias et al., 2020). However, we did 445 not observe such proximity of lipid droplets and SARS-CoV-2 particles or DMVs by 446 using various high-resolution imaging techniques (Cortese et al., 2020), although 447 recent reports suggest that inhibition of lipid droplet formation interferes with the 448 SARS-CoV-2 replication cycle (Dias et al., 2020; Williams et al., 2021). Further 449 studies will be required to clarify whether lipid droplets contribute to some specific 450 steps of the SARS-CoV-2 life cycle or are more generally required as lipid or energy 451 source. 452 In conclusion, we show that although ATG5-12/16L1-dependent autophagy is 453 dispensable for HCV and SARS-CoV-2 replication, components of the 454 autophagosome biogenesis machinery such as elements of the PI3K complex and 455 DFCP1 are critically involved in viral replication, most likely by contributing to the 456 formation of DMVs, the viral sites of RNA replication.
